**Short answer:** YES


----------


**Long answer:**

If the variables `x1,x2,x3,x4` in `X` represent the same things as variables `x3,x2,x1,x4` in `X-new`, **then yes**.

The reason is simple. Think about the following. Let's say that `x1` is the age of some people. You train the model and then you have a `weight (w)` for this variable.

Next, if you try to predict the `X_new`, this trained `weight` will be used. But now, it is going to be applied on another variable (i.e. `x3` and not `x1`).

# Issue 
The problem is the extra `ToList()`.

It should be:
`listItems.InsertRange(0, filteredMakes.ToList());`

*However this will create duplicates as the items are added to the beginning of the list, but not removed from their original spots.*

# Solutions 

## A. Add + Insert(0

You could create a new list and then enumerate the original list and call `Add` or `Instert(0, ...)` depending if the model is a top model or not. 

## B. Order by

Option 2. You could order the list by 'does_it_belong_to_top_models'

```
var l1 = new List<int>() { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 };
var supers = new List<int>() { 2, 5 };

var ordered = l1.OrderBy(i1 => supers.Any(i2 => i1 == i2) ? -1 : 1 );

Console.WriteLine(string.Join(",", ordered));
```
Output
```
2,5,1,3,4,6
```

items.body_markdown:
I like Python for the relative importing between modules and code conciseness. When performing operations on a large number of datasets, I would use python as the main framework, the computationally heavy parts could then be handled by plug and play modules coded in faster languages like FORTRAN.

In my current state I have a package called ```sigmareader```, which is essentially a class; the class is defined in the ```__init__.py``` while the methods are called from their respective packages. The structure of ```sigmareader``` is shown below:

```
sigmareader
├── __init__.py
├── _reader
│   ├── ...
├── ...
```
To read my data I create an instance of ```sigmareader``` and use the ```reader``` method. The read data in stored in suitable form in the instance's ```self``` attribute.

This is in itself quite a computationally heavy task. Now with the data read and stored, I would like to proceed with product calculation. I foresee product computation would be equally complex and computationally heavy, thus I would like to make it a separate package called ```sigmaproduct```:

```
sigmaproduct
├── __init__.py
├── _cloudproduct
│   ├── ...
├── ...
```

Product calculation requires inputting read data which is stored in the instance of ```sigmareader```. I see three ways of doing so. 

__First approach__
Make ```sigmaproduct``` a child class of ```sigmareader```. 

To illustrate workflow:
```
sigmaproduct_ins = sigmaproduct()

for dataset in dataset_lst:
    sigmaproduct_ins.reader(dataset) # storing read data in instance
    sigmaproduct_ins.cloudproduct() # reading and storing cloudproduct in instance

    ...further operations
```

__Second approach__
Make ```sigmaproduct``` an independent class, which initializes using an instance of ```sigmareader```. Where that instance of ```sigmareader``` has already activated it's methods; i.e. it has already stored the read data under it's ```self``` attribute. 

To illustrate workflow:
```
sigmareader_ins = sigmareader()

for dataset in dataset_lst:
    sigmareader_ins.reader(dataset) # storing read data in instance
    sigmaproduct_ins = sigmaproduct(sigmareader_ins) # creating instance of sigmaproduct
    sigmaproduct_ins.cloudproduct() # reading and storing cloudproduct in instance

    ...further operations
```

__Third approach__
Make ```sigmaproduct``` an independent class, it initializes as a generic object just as ```sigmareader```; i.e. it's initialization is independent of the dataset. Instead, the methods of ```sigmaproduct``` would require inputs of an instance of ```sigmareader``` to compute the products.

To illustrate the workflow:
```
sigmareader_ins = sigmareader()
sigmaproduct_ins = sigmaproduct()

for dataset in dataset_lst:
    sigmareader_ins.reader(dataset) #storing read data in instance
    sigmaproduct_ins.cloudproduct(sigmareader_ins) #computing and storing data stored in sigmareader_ins

    ... futher operations
```


----------

With the many different methods in each package, I would like as much as possible to keep ```sigmareader``` and ```sigmaproduct``` as independent classes, thus I prefer not to use the __First approach__. 

However, ```dataset_lst``` contains a LARGE number of ```dataset```s, thus I am seeking for the computationally most optimum approach. Which is the best? What are the *pros and cons* of each approach? Are there any other more optimum approaches that I am missing out?
items.title: Is it better to create an inherited class or a class that initializes using an instance of parent object?

You are given an array of size \(N\) with entries \(P_i\). You are allowed to pick exactly one element from the array
each day. Also, at the end of each day, the value of all the elements of the array is reduced to \(50\% \) of the value at
the start of the day. This means if an entry in the array on a specific day is  \(P_i\), then it is reduced to    \(P_i/2\) at the
end of the day.

Note

1. The division performed is the integer division
2. Any element once picked can not be picked again.

You are also provided with \(Q\) queries.
Each query contains a number \(K_i)\. You have to determine the number of ways to select the elements of the array
such that the sum of values that are selected is /(ge K_i \).

Input format:

First line: \(T\) denoting the number of test cases
For each test case:

First line: An integer \(N\) denoting the size of the array
Next line: \(N\) space-separated integers \(P_i\ ) denoting values of elements of the array on the first day
o Next line: An integer \(Q\), the number of queries
Next line: \(Q\) space separated integers \(K_i \)

Output format:
For each test case, print a single line containing \(Q\) space-separated integers denoting the number of ways to
pick the elements of the array in such a way that the sum of values picked is \(ge K_i\) .

Constraints:
\(1\le T\le 10\\ 1\le N\le 8\\1\le Q \le 10^5\\0 \le P_i \le 10^8\\ 0\le k_i\ le 10^9\\\\)
Sample input :
1
3
3 8 10
2
13 15

Sample Output: 3 0

Explanation

For obtaining a sum of >=13, there are 3 ways

WAY 1: Pick entry 2 at day 1 at 8, entry 3 at day 2 at 10/2 and entry 1 at 3/4 8+5+0=13

WAY 2: Pick entry 3 at day 1 at 10. entry 1 at day 2 at 3/2 and entry 2 at 8/4 10+1+2=13
WAY 3: Pick entry 3 at day 1 at 10, entry 2 at day 2 at 8/2 and entry 1 at 3/4 = 10+4+0=14
There is no way of obtaining a sum of >=15
Time limit : 1sec for each input

I tried this solve it  but not getting answer

useReducer - Dispatch does NOT seem to Work

answers.body_markdown:
In `frontend` sections, `http-request redirect` is handled fairly early in the process, so you **cannot** do something like this (which you appear to have tried, already, without success)...

    frontend web
        use_backend site1 if { hdr(host) -i site1.example.com }
        use_backend site2 if { hdr(host) -i site2.example.com }
        http-request redirect location https://site1.example.com 

HAProxy "allows" this configuration, but it does not work, because:

    [WARNING] : parsing [/etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg:xx] : a 'http-request' rule placed after a 'use_backend' rule will still be processed before.

`use_backend` rules are always deferred until after `http-request` rules are processed.

However, HAProxy supports `http-request redirect` in backend sections, too, so you can defer the interpretation of `http-request redirect` by placing it in a backend section that exists solely for the purpose of catching anything not caught by `use_backend`.  

Create a "dummy" backend with no servers, and a redirect rule, and set that new backend as your default backend.

    frontend web
        use_backend site1 if { hdr(host) -i site1.example.com }
        use_backend site2 if { hdr(host) -i site2.example.com }
        default_backend catchall

    backend catchall
        mode http
        http-request redirect location https://site1.example.com 
        # no 'server' declared here

`default_backend` is used only when no `use_backend` statement has been matched, after they have all been considered.  It can be placed anywhere in the `frontend` configuration since it is automatically evaluated last, when there are no other possibilities.

`catchall` has no special meaning. It's just an arbitrary label for this new backend.

```python

```

I can see a number of ways you might go according to the Python style guide ([PEP8][1]). I am working with a capable C# developer who is not experienced in Python, and we're working on a small internal API. I want him to be able to read code easily and quickly.

Would the Pythonistas among us leave the code as above, and keep the line at 98 chars long? Or use a backslash to break the `if` across lines:

```python
def pytest_generate_tests2a(metafunc):
    if 'cvcorpus_docx' in metafunc.fixturenames and \
          'cvcorpus_expected' in metafunc.fixturenames:
        actual_expected = cv_testcorpus_actual_expected()
        metafunc.parametrize("cvcorpus_docx,cvcorpus_expected", actual_expected)
```

Or would you bracket the big boolean expression so you don't need a backslash?

```python
def pytest_generate_tests2b(metafunc):
    if ('cvcorpus_docx' in metafunc.fixturenames and
          'cvcorpus_expected' in metafunc.fixturenames):
        actual_expected = cv_testcorpus_actual_expected()
        metafunc.parametrize("cvcorpus_docx,cvcorpus_expected", actual_expected)
```

Do `2a` and `2b` get confusing around indentation?

or would you go for a more functional approach and avoid the long line that way:

```python
def pytest_generate_tests3(metafunc):
    ae_pair = ('cvcorpus_docx', 'cvcorpus_expected')
    if all(ae in metafunc.fixturenames for ae in ae_pair):
        actual_expected = cv_testcorpus_actual_expected()
        metafunc.parametrize(','.join(ae_pair), actual_expected)
```

answers.title: Too many connections error when I connect in a loop

answers.body_markdown:
Stack Overflow is taken by many as a service to provide a quick fix to an immediate problem at hand. 

Unfortunately, it is also a source of the reusable code examples. And when you look at this site from such a point of view, you will find most answers *appalling*, as they create more problems than solve. 

Take, for example, this post. The code in the OP is wrong on *many* levels, essentially misusing a prepared statement, ditching *all* its benefits. Well, it's all right, actually, as we are all learning. But the *answer* is leaving all the problems intact, focusing on a single particular problem. As a result, we have an *approved by the community* code example that is, actually, *extremely harmful*. All right, I've got some experience to tell a bad code. But an unsuspecting visitor from Google doesn't. And would simply copy and paste the offered solution. Along with all its vulnerabilities and inefficiency. 

To run a prepared statement in a loop:

- of course the connection should be made before the loop
 - besides, all the connection code have to be moved outside the loop, not only a part of it
 - besides, it have to be a correct connection code, with all the required options, so it won't introduce new problems in the future (caused by the wrong `charset` for example)
- the prepared statement should be the actual prepared statement, not an imitation. **All variables in the query must be replaced with placeholders** to make this prepared statement actually do anything useful - preventing an **SQL injection** in the first place.
- the `prepare()` call must be **moved out of the loop** as well. That's the very point of such a statement - *prepare* once, execute multiple.
- the error handling code must be secure and flexible. While `echo "Error: " . $e->getMessage();` is anything than it.

So the correct example would be:

    include 'pdo.php';
    $sql = "INSERT INTO Growth(id, date, stage, length, width)
    VALUES(nullif(?,'NULL'), nullif(?,'NULL'), nullif(?,'NULL'), nullif(?,'NULL'), nullif(?,'NULL')")
    $stmt = $dbcon->prepare($sql);
    while(($emapData = fgetcsv($file, 10000, ",")) !== FALSE){    
        $stmt->execute($emapData);
    }

Two assumptions were made in this code:

- the `pdo.php` file contains a [correct PDO connection code](https://phpdelusions.net/pdo_examples/connect_to_mysql) as instead of connecting in the every file the connection code must be moved in a separate file and then just included in every script that requires a database connection
- the number of columns in the csv file is equal to the number of rows in the table. Otherwise, an `array_slice()` function must be called on `$emapData` beforehand

You can use `cv2.goodFeaturesToTrack()` for corner detection. The function takes four parameters

```
corners = cv2.goodFeaturesToTrack(image, maxCorners, qualityLevel, minDistance)
```

* `image` - Input 8-bit or floating-point 32-bit grayscale single-channel image
* `maxCorners` - Maximum number of corners to return
* `qualityLevel` - Minimum accepted quality level of corners between 0-1. All corners below quality level are rejected 
* `minDistance` - Minimum possible Euclidean distance between corners

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

```
import cv2

image = cv2.imread('1.png')
gray = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)

corners = cv2.goodFeaturesToTrack(gray,10,0.2,20)

for corner in corners:
    x,y = corner.ravel()
    cv2.circle(image,(x,y),5,(36,255,12),-1)

cv2.imshow('image', image)
cv2.waitKey()
```


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/wRb6R.png

items.body_markdown:
I am trying to understand the correct usage of L2 regularization with MLP classifiers and Regressors. I am currently studying this description: [regularization][1]


I am also looking at SciKit Learn's implementation [here][2].
The `_backprop` method is (removing comments):
```
def _backprop(self, X, y, activations, deltas, coef_grads,
                  intercept_grads):

n_samples = X.shape[0]

        # Forward propagate
        activations = self._forward_pass(activations)

        # Get loss
        loss_func_name = self.loss
        if loss_func_name == 'log_loss' and self.out_activation_ == 'logistic':
            loss_func_name = 'binary_log_loss'
        loss = LOSS_FUNCTIONS[loss_func_name](y, activations[-1])
        # Add L2 regularization term to loss
        values = np.sum(
            np.array([np.dot(s.ravel(), s.ravel()) for s in self.coefs_]))
        loss += (0.5 * self.alpha) * values / n_samples

        # Backward propagate
        last = self.n_layers_ - 2

        # The calculation of delta[last] here works with following
        # combinations of output activation and loss function:
        # sigmoid and binary cross entropy, softmax and categorical cross
        # entropy, and identity with squared loss
        deltas[last] = activations[-1] - y

        # Compute gradient for the last layer
        coef_grads, intercept_grads = self._compute_loss_grad(
            last, n_samples, activations, deltas, coef_grads, intercept_grads)

        # Iterate over the hidden layers
        for i in range(self.n_layers_ - 2, 0, -1):
            deltas[i - 1] = safe_sparse_dot(deltas[i], self.coefs_[i].T)
            inplace_derivative = DERIVATIVES[self.activation]
            inplace_derivative(activations[i], deltas[i - 1])

            coef_grads, intercept_grads = self._compute_loss_grad(
                i - 1, n_samples, activations, deltas, coef_grads,
                intercept_grads)

        return loss, coef_grads, intercept_grads
```
It returns the loss as one three return params. But in this method itself, loss is not used, even though it has the L2 regularization value appended. Please not the `deltas[last] = activations[-1] - y` term. This is the initial gradient calculation. Works for both regression (with MSE loss) and classification (with cross entropy loss). But shouldn't the regularization term be added to this? Otherwise the regularization term seems to not be used at all in backpropagation and updating the weights.

The above method is called from `_fit_stochastic`. 

Relevant code:

```
batch_loss, coef_grads, intercept_grads = self._backprop(
                        X[batch_slice], y[batch_slice], activations, deltas,
                        coef_grads, intercept_grads)
                    accumulated_loss += batch_loss * (batch_slice.stop -
                                                      batch_slice.start)

                    # update weights
                    grads = coef_grads + intercept_grads
                    self._optimizer.update_params(grads)
```
`batch_loss` is only used to modify `accumulated_loss`, which keep a check on how much loss the model is accumulating. The weights are updated in `self._optimizer.update_params(grads)`, but the regularization term has no effect here.

If regularization is not used, this makes sense as the final activation - the expected result becomes the loss gradient. However, since regularization is used, shouldn't the L2 reg parameter be appended to the loss, and be used for each weight update?

  [1]: http://www.deeplearningbook.org/contents/regularization.html
  [2]: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/master/sklearn/neural_network/_multilayer_perceptron.py

The problem lies within `angular5-data-table`. Its [DataTable.html][1] tries to access the private method `resizeColumnStart` of [DataTableComponent][2] class. 

Why this doesn't work when building your `Angular` application for production (with AOT), is explained at https://stackoverflow.com/a/43177386/2358409.

Please note that according to Angular documentation ([Coosing a compiler][3]),  `ng build --prod` compiles with AOT by default. Hence your problem could be solved in the following two ways. 

 1. Replace `angular5-data-table` module by an up-to-date table module (i.e. [Angular Material Table][4]) 
 2. Disable AOT when building the application for production (`ng build --prod --aot=false`)


  [1]: https://github.com/brunano21/angular-4-data-table/blob/master/libs/datatable/src/components/table/table.component.html
  [2]: https://github.com/brunano21/angular-4-data-table/blob/master/libs/datatable/src/components/table/table.component.ts

answers.body_markdown:
You can do this with a VBS script, something like:

    set wshell = wscript.createobject("wscript.shell")
    
    msg = "<No message provided>"
    title = "Information"
    timeout = 0
    
    if wscript.arguments.count > 0 then
        msg = wscript.arguments.item(0)
        if wscript.arguments.count > 1 then
            title = wscript.arguments.item(1)
            if wscript.arguments.count > 2 then
                timeout = wscript.arguments.item(2)
            end if
        end if
    end if
    
    wscript.quit(wshell.popup(msg, timeout, title, 0))

Just put that into `paxmsg.vbs` and call it with:

    cscript /nologo paxmsg.vbs "My text"
or:

    cscript /nologo paxmsg.vbs "Text with 5s timeout" "My Title" 5

The basic usage is <sup>(a)</sup>:

    cscript /nologo paxmsg.vbs <optionalText> <optionalTitle> <optionalTimeout>
and you can discern the default values for each parameter from the first few lines of the script itself.

`ERRORLEVEL` can be used in your batch script to detect whether `OK` was pressed or it timed out (assuming non-zero timeout value, of course).

---

By way, of example, the following invocation:

    cscript /nologo paxmsg.vbs "Dialog box with sample text" "Pax's dialog box"

results in:

> [![enter image description here][1]][1]

---

<sup>(a)</sup> Note that using `cscript` is most likely the behaviour you want, in that it will wait until the dialog box *closes* before continuing on with your batch script. If you want it to continue immediately, you can use `wscript` instead.

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/ChOZS.png

answers.body_markdown:
You're missing 2 lines of code. 

After `server.ehlo()`, you need:
```
    server.starttls()
    server.ehlo()
``` 

`server.starttls()` is necessary since it tells an email server that an email client wants to turn an existing insecure connection into a secure one.

The second `server.ehlo()` after `server.starttls()` is needed because after completing the TLS handshake, the SMTP protocol is reset to its initial state.

I’m afraid this isn’t as tested as I’d like it to be, but what strikes me is that you’re not listening to the client before sending data to it. My hypothesis is that Chrome may be detecting that somehow so /maybe/ adding a receive might make a difference.

To be sure though, you could try using Wireshark to monitor the request and compare with the traffic sent request to a full server, which should help diagnose differences.
answers.title: Simple HTTP server using socket programming in C failed on Chrome

answers.body_markdown:
Such kind of problems typically occur when the server is closing the connection while there are still unread data from the client. In your case the server is closing the connection without reading the request from the client. But even if you've read the full request the problem might still happen since the client might have sent multiple requests (HTTP pipelining).

The HTTP standard even has a recommendation how a proper close should be done and specifically addresses the problem you get. From [RFC 7230 section 6.6 "Tear-down"](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-6.6):

> If a server performs an immediate close of a TCP connection, there is
   a significant risk that the client will not be able to read the last
   HTTP response.  If the server receives additional data from the
   client on a fully closed connection, such as another request that was
   sent by the client before receiving the server's response, __the
   server's TCP stack will send a reset packet to the client__;
   unfortunately, the reset packet might erase the client's
   unacknowledged input buffers before they can be read and interpreted
   by the client's HTTP parser.

>  __To avoid the TCP reset problem, servers typically close a connection
   in stages__.  First, the server performs a half-close by closing only
   the write side of the read/write connection.  __The server then
   continues to read from the connection until it receives a
   corresponding close by the client__, or until the server is reasonably
   certain that its own TCP stack has received the client's
   acknowledgement of the packet(s) containing the server's last
   response.  Finally, the server fully closes the connection.

Apart from that: it is strongly recommended (SHOULD in the standard) that you clearly mark the size of the body either by using a `Content-length` header or by using chunked transfer encoding - instead of just closing the connection. It is also strongly recommended that you signal the client that no more requests will be  accepted on this connection by adding a `Connection: close` header.

In general: HTTP is way more complex then one might think just by looking at a few examples. [There is a standard](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230) which describes how clients and server should behave and there is a reason that this standard is long. Please follow it nevertheless if you intend to implement your own HTTP stack instead of just using existing implementations.

answers.title: How to resize the window obtained from cv2.imshow()?

answers.body_markdown:
The actual "problem" comes from [`imshow`](https://docs.opencv.org/4.1.1/d7/dfc/group__highgui.html#ga453d42fe4cb60e5723281a89973ee563) itself, and is the following:

> If the window was not created before this function, it is assumed creating a window with [`cv::WINDOW_AUTOSIZE`](https://docs.opencv.org/4.1.1/d7/dfc/group__highgui.html#ggabf7d2c5625bc59ac130287f925557ac3acf621ace7a54954cbac01df27e47228f).

Looking at the corresponding description at the [`WindowFlags`](https://docs.opencv.org/4.1.1/d7/dfc/group__highgui.html#gabf7d2c5625bc59ac130287f925557ac3) documentation page, we get:

> the user cannot resize the window, the size is constrainted by the image displayed. 

So, to work around this, you must set up the window manually using [`namedWindow`](https://docs.opencv.org/4.1.1/d7/dfc/group__highgui.html#ga5afdf8410934fd099df85c75b2e0888b), and then resize it accordingly using [`resizeWindow`](https://docs.opencv.org/4.1.1/d7/dfc/group__highgui.html#ga9e80e080f7ef33f897e415358aee7f7e).

Let's see this code snippet:

```python
import cv2

# Read image
image = cv2.imread('path/to/your/image.png')

# Window from plain imshow() command
cv2.imshow('Window from plain imshow()', image)

# Custom window
cv2.namedWindow('custom window', cv2.WINDOW_KEEPRATIO)
cv2.imshow('custom window', image)
cv2.resizeWindow('custom window', 200, 200)

cv2.waitKey(0)
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
```

An exemplary output would look like this (original image size is `[400, 400]`):

[![Output][1]][1]

Using `cv2.WINDOW_KEEPRATIO`, the image is always fitted to the window, and you can resize the window manually, if you want.

Hope that helps!


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/ArCOV.png
answers.title: How to resize the window obtained from cv2.imshow()?

items.body_markdown:
Is there any way to get **probe argument names and/or data types** for SystemTAP and/or DTrace SDTs at runtime from `stap`, `dtrace`, `perf`, etc so these tools can automatically show SDT arguments in the correct format, capture string values, etc?

----

I've embedded a suite of SystemTAP / DTrace compatible statically defined user-space tracepoints (SDTs) in my software to provide tracing facilities in production.

I'm using SystemTAP's `dtrace` binary to generate the trace macro header. (I haven't been able to try "real" DTrace yet. But the documentation suggests it behaves much the same with regards to the issues I mention below).

Overall it works well, but I've been very surprised and frustrated to find that while I can and do specify the data types and names of probe arguments in my `probes.d` they appear to be used *only* to determine the argument count.

**The probe names and types don't seem to be recorded anywhere.** `perf` and `stap` don't seem to have any idea what the types of the names and probe arguments are at runtime:

* `perf list` shows only `sdt_myprovider:tracepointname` with no indication of arguments at all.
* After `perf probe 'sdt_myprovider:tracepointname'` and `perf record -e 'sdt_myprovider:tracepointname' -aR`, if I `perf script` the output shows just `argn=xxxxxx` where `argn` is `arg1` through `arg9` and `xxxxx` is always a long-int value.  
* `stap -L 'process("/path/to/binary").provider("myprovider").mark("*")'` prints all arguments as `$arg1` .. `$arg9` with data type `long`.
* If I define a SystemTAP probe I can seemingly only access the arguments as `$arg1` etc, with type `long`. I can get the tracepoint name in `$$name` but there's no indication the argument names are available.

For example, this tracepoint has the `probes.d` definition:

    probe sync__copy__table__synchronous(uint32 sub_id, uint32 remoterelid, const char *nspname, const char *relname);

and `perf script` reports the following, with `arg3` and `arg4` represented as the values of the pointers to the strings:

    postgres  3032 [001] 422927.342271:     sdt_pgl:sync__copy__table__synchronous: (7fb655cb947a) arg1=2667578509 arg2=16393 arg3=21536480 arg4=21548016
    postgres  3032 [001] 422927.344527:     sdt_pgl:sync__copy__table__synchronous: (7fb655cb947a) arg1=2667578509 arg2=18892 arg3=21548168 arg4=21548200
    postgres  3032 [001] 422927.345674:     sdt_pgl:sync__copy__table__synchronous: (7fb655cb947a) arg1=2667578509 arg2=16410 arg3=21548344 arg4=21548376

Looking at the macros in the generated `probes.h` shows that the only appearance of the argument name and data type from `probes.d` is in the probe definition as it appears in a *comment*, e.g.:

```
/* TRACE_PGL_SYNC_COPY_TABLE_SYNCHRONOUS ( unsigned int sub_id, unsigned int remoterelid, const char * nspname, const char * relname ) */
#if defined STAP_SDT_V1
#define TRACE_PGL_SYNC_COPY_TABLE_SYNCHRONOUS_ENABLED() __builtin_expect (sync__copy__table__synchronous_semaphore, 0)
#define pgl_sync__copy__table__synchronous_semaphore sync__copy__table__synchronous_semaphore
#else
#define TRACE_PGL_SYNC_COPY_TABLE_SYNCHRONOUS_ENABLED() __builtin_expect (pgl_sync__copy__table__synchronous_semaphore, 0)
#endif
__extension__ extern unsigned short pgl_sync__copy__table__synchronous_semaphore __attribute__ ((unused)) __attribute__ ((section (".probes")));
#define TRACE_PGL_SYNC_COPY_TABLE_SYNCHRONOUS(arg1, arg2, arg3, arg4) \
DTRACE_PROBE4 (pgl, sync__copy__table__synchronous, arg1, arg2, arg3, arg4)
```

So am I correct in concluding that there's just no way to embed the tracepoint argument names and types in the compiled-in tracepoint definition in a way that `stap`, `perf` etc can access and use?

It's *intensely* frustrating, as both tools support capturing and displaying argument types and names with regular DWARF debuginfo-driven dynamic userspace probes. So the static probe points are actually considerably inferior in some ways, despite their relative stability, somewhat self-documenting nature, etc.

Most importantly and annoyingly this means that if I'm capturing trace information from SystemTAP I have to write a probe definition for each and every tracepoint so that I can correctly capture *string values* by manually using the SystemTAP function `user_string($argn)` on the argument. There appears to be *no way whatsoever* to capture string-valued arguments to SDTs from `perf` either.

e.g.

    probe process("someproc").library("myproviderlib").provider("myprovider").mark("trace__point__name")
    {
        printf("[%d] %s: subid=%u relid=%u rel=%s.%s\n", pid(), $$name, $arg1, $arg2, user_string($arg3), user_string($arg4));
    }

What I really want is some kind of way to to embed a probe descriptor into the `.probes` ELF section. Something that `perf` and `stap` etc can read and use to look up tracepoint args names and types.

Am I just out of luck?
items.title: How to save the data types of DTrace/SystemTAP SDT argument types for tracepoints

answers.body_markdown:
Actually, later I also found out we can insert and pass on a function  instead of passing in a popupContent (html).

Where to change it:

    layer.bindPopup(popupContent, {maxHeight: 400});

instead of original variable as html insertion:

     var popupContent = '<table>\
                <tr>\
                    <td colspan="2"><strong>Lot</strong><br />' + (feature.properties['Lot'] !== null ? Autolinker.link(String(feature.properties['Lot'])) : '') + '</td>\
                </tr>\
                <tr>\
                    <th scope="row">Design</th>\
                    <td>' + (feature.properties['Design'] !== null ? Autolinker.link(String(feature.properties['Design'])) : '') + '</td>\
                </tr>\
                <tr>\
                    <th scope="row">Area (sqm)</th>\
                    <td>' + (feature.properties['Area (sqm)'] !== null ? Autolinker.link(String(feature.properties['Area (sqm)'])) : '') + '</td>\
                </tr>\
            </table>';

we can replace it with a function to change front-end effect:
e.g.

    function popup(){
                    //do whatever here
                }
                
    layer.bindPopup(popup, {maxHeight: 400});
            

Idea inspired also by the Answer and  its documentation: https://leafletjs.com/reference-1.5.0.html#popup 


setContent

(<String|HTMLElement|Function> htmlContent)	
Sets the HTML content of the popup. If a function is passed the source layer will be passed to the function. The function should return a String or HTMLElement to be used in the popup.

Hope everyone enjoy this :)

answers.body_markdown:
As it turns out the answer was to provide an alternative url for ADFS to retrieve the SAML metadata file from our system.

It seems ADFS cannot handle having query strings into its "relying party trust" "Federation metadata file location" (this ADFS jargon is killing me ...)
[![enter image description here][1]][1]

anyway, once the url could be used without query strings, all worked fine.
We moved the parameters to be part of the url:

instead of
```
https://our-domain/users/auth/saml/metadata?attr1=123&attr2=432
```

we monkey-patched omniauth-saml and used a new url so we could provide the same functionality with the alternative url:
```
https://our-domain/users/auth/saml/:attr1/:attr2/metadata
```



  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/nLLyO.png

You can specify the count and ignore the case with the provided arguments in re.sub().


    import re
    names = ['MisterClarkKent','Mrs.Carol','missjanedoemiss', 'mrjasontoddmr']
    filter_names = [re.sub(r'mrs?\.?|mister\s?|miss\s?', r'',name, count=1, flags=re.IGNORECASE) for name in names]
    
    filter_names
    
    Out[99]: ['ClarkKent', 'Carol', 'janedoemiss', 'jasontoddmr']

The `?` means the character is optional so in `mrs?\.?` bother `s` and `.` are optional so it can capture both `mr or mr.` and `mrs or mrs.`.

    assert ex.match(f'Invalid value "{val}" for int param "n"')
```

When Hypothesis sets `val = 1e+16`, I get a failure.

The printed output for that failure is:

Invalid value "1e+16" for int param "n"|Invalid value "1e+16" for int param "n"|True
```

answers.body_markdown:
Make sure your query is fully-aggregated otherwise Esper must retain the events since the select-clause is asking for event data. When the query is fully-aggregated Esper retainw only aggregated data and that is what you want.

This is not fully aggregated:

    select a, b, count(*) from Event group by a

This is better and fully aggregated:

    select a, b, count(*) from Event group by a, b

The doc for this is [here][1].


  [1]: http://esper.espertech.com/release-8.3.0/reference-esper/html_single/index.html#processingmodel_aggregation_batch_group_agg

answers.body_markdown:
`collections.Counter` is also designed for this type of task, and can easily be converted into a pandas dataframe.

    from collections import Counter
    txt = "chilli mango chilli mango grape"
    words = txt.split()
    counts = Counter(words)  # Counter({'chilli': 2, 'grape': 1, 'mango': 2})
    df = pd.DataFrame(counts.items(), columns=["Word", "Frequency"])  # same data as a dataframe

You could also build a dataframe like this to avoid creating duplicates:

    mytable = pd.DataFrame(columns=["word", "frequency"]).set_index("word")
    for word in words:
        if word in mytable.index:
            mytable.loc[word] += 1
        else:
            mytable.loc[word] = 1

   
Having said that your existing code should actually work if you drop the `keep = False` (which tells it to remove *all* duplicates, including the first copy) and change `"First name"`to `"word"`.

answers.body_markdown:
A regexp looking for either quoted substrings or words:

    import re
    string = 'Hello, I am "Jeff Watson" from NY.'
    [next(x for x in m if x)
        for m in re.findall(r'"([^"]*)"|\'([^\']*)\'|(\w+)', string)]

(Also, try to avoid using `str` as a variable name in Python, as it normally holds the string type.)

Here's another method:

    [m[1] for m in re.findall(r'(["\'])?((?(1).*?\1|\w+))', string)]

how to render a model in another component?

answers.body_markdown:
This is what I usually do it. All calculation and plotting are based on [water year (`WY`) or hydrologic year from October to September](http://glossary.ametsoc.org/wiki/Water_year). 

<!-- language-all: lang-r -->


    library(tidyverse)
    library(lubridate)

    set.seed(123)

    Dates30s <- data.frame(seq(as.Date("2011-01-01"), to = as.Date("2040-12-31"), by = "day"))
    colnames(Dates30s) <- "date"
    FakeData <- data.frame(A = runif(10958, min = 0.3, max = 1.5), 
                           B = runif(10958, min = 1.2, max = 2), 
                           C = runif(10958, min = 0.6, max = 1.8))

    ### Calculate Year, Month then Water year (WY) and Season
    myData <- data.frame(Dates30s, FakeData) %>% 
      mutate(Year = year(date),
             MonthNr = month(date),
             Month = month(date, label = TRUE, abbr = TRUE)) %>% 
      mutate(WY = case_when(MonthNr > 9 ~ Year + 1,
                            TRUE      ~ Year)) %>% 
      mutate(Season = case_when(MonthNr %in%  9:11  ~ "Fall",
                                MonthNr %in%  c(12, 1, 2) ~ "Winter",
                                MonthNr %in%  3:5   ~ "Spring",
                                TRUE ~ "Summer")) %>% 
      select(-date, -MonthNr, -Year) %>% 
      as_tibble()
    myData
    #> # A tibble: 10,958 x 6
    #>        A     B     C Month    WY Season
    #>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <ord> <dbl> <chr> 
    #>  1 0.645  1.37 1.51  Jan    2011 Winter
    #>  2 1.25   1.79 1.71  Jan    2011 Winter
    #>  3 0.791  1.35 1.68  Jan    2011 Winter
    #>  4 1.36   1.97 0.646 Jan    2011 Winter
    #>  5 1.43   1.31 1.60  Jan    2011 Winter
    #>  6 0.355  1.52 0.708 Jan    2011 Winter
    #>  7 0.934  1.94 0.825 Jan    2011 Winter
    #>  8 1.37   1.89 1.03  Jan    2011 Winter
    #>  9 0.962  1.75 0.632 Jan    2011 Winter
    #> 10 0.848  1.94 0.883 Jan    2011 Winter
    #> # ... with 10,948 more rows

Calculate seasonal and monthly average by WY

    ### Seasonal Avg by WY
    SeasonalAvg <- myData %>%  
      select(-Month) %>% 
      group_by(WY, Season) %>% 
      summarise_all(mean, na.rm = TRUE) %>% 
      ungroup() %>% 
      gather(key = "State", value = "MFI", -WY, -Season)
    SeasonalAvg
    #> # A tibble: 366 x 4
    #>       WY Season State   MFI
    #>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <dbl>
    #>  1  2011 Fall   A     0.939
    #>  2  2011 Spring A     0.907
    #>  3  2011 Summer A     0.896
    #>  4  2011 Winter A     0.909
    #>  5  2012 Fall   A     0.895
    #>  6  2012 Spring A     0.865
    #>  7  2012 Summer A     0.933
    #>  8  2012 Winter A     0.895
    #>  9  2013 Fall   A     0.879
    #> 10  2013 Spring A     0.872
    #> # ... with 356 more rows

    ### Monthly Avg by WY
    MonthlyAvg <- myData %>%  
      select(-Season) %>% 
      group_by(WY, Month) %>% 
      summarise_all(mean, na.rm = TRUE) %>% 
      ungroup() %>% 
      gather(key = "State", value = "MFI", -WY, -Month) %>% 
      mutate(Month = factor(Month))
    MonthlyAvg
    #> # A tibble: 1,080 x 4
    #>       WY Month State   MFI
    #>    <dbl> <ord> <chr> <dbl>
    #>  1  2011 Jan   A     1.00 
    #>  2  2011 Feb   A     0.807
    #>  3  2011 Mar   A     0.910
    #>  4  2011 Apr   A     0.923
    #>  5  2011 May   A     0.888
    #>  6  2011 Jun   A     0.876
    #>  7  2011 Jul   A     0.909
    #>  8  2011 Aug   A     0.903
    #>  9  2011 Sep   A     0.939
    #> 10  2012 Jan   A     0.903
    #> # ... with 1,070 more rows


Plot seasonal and monthly data

    ### Seasonal plot
    s1 <- ggplot(SeasonalAvg, aes(x = Season, y = MFI, color = State)) +
      geom_boxplot(position = position_dodge(width = 0.7)) +
      geom_point(position = position_jitterdodge(seed = 123))
    s1

![](https://i.imgur.com/wia5K0v.png)


    ### Monthly plot
    m1 <- ggplot(MonthlyAvg, aes(x = Month, y = MFI, color = State)) +
      geom_boxplot(position = position_dodge(width = 0.7)) +
      geom_point(position = position_jitterdodge(seed = 123))
    m1

![](https://i.imgur.com/D2uDuqw.png)


Bonus

    ### https://stackoverflow.com/a/58369424/786542
    # if (!require(devtools)) {
    #   install.packages('devtools')
    # }
    # devtools::install_github('erocoar/gghalves')
    library(gghalves)
    s2 <- ggplot(SeasonalAvg, aes(x = Season, y = MFI, color = State)) +
      geom_half_boxplot(nudge = 0.05) +
      geom_half_violin(aes(fill = State),
                       side = "r", nudge = 0.01) +
      theme_light() +
      theme(legend.position = "bottom") +
      guides(fill = guide_legend(nrow = 1))
    s2

![](https://i.imgur.com/aB3DSpa.png)


    s3 <- ggplot(SeasonalAvg, aes(x = Season, y = MFI, color = State)) +
      geom_half_boxplot(nudge = 0.05, outlier.color = NA) +
      geom_dotplot(aes(fill = State),
                   binaxis = "y", method = "histodot", 
                   dotsize = 0.35, 
                   stackdir = "up", position = PositionDodge) +
      theme_light() +
      theme(legend.position = "bottom") +
      guides(color = guide_legend(nrow = 1))
    s3
    #> `stat_bindot()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

![](https://i.imgur.com/JRp9H9s.png)

    library(tidyverse)

    Spring = SeasonalData %>% filter(Month == 3 | Month == 4 |Month == 5)
    Winter1 = SeasonalData %>% filter(Month == 12)
    Winter1$Year = Winter1$Year+1
    Winter2 = SeasonalData %>%  filter(Month == 1 | Month == 2 )
    Winter = rbind(Winter1, Winter2) %>%  filter(Year >= 2012 & Year <= 2040) %>% group_by(Year) %>% summarise_all(funs(mean)) %>% select(-"Month")
    BoxData = gather(Winter, key = "Variable", value = "value", -Year )
